ZIF-67 type metal organic framework (MOF) has been synthesized and pyrolyzed at six different temperatures to prepare cobalt nanoparticles encapsulated by carbon. In the pyrolysis step, N content of the organic linker in ZIF-67 synthesis helped to prepare N doped carbon and Co-N moieties. Dielectric barrier plasma (DBP) has been used in succession with pyrolysis to benefit from its less destructive effects during decomposition to generate more active sites through lattice distortion. All catalysts have been characterized and tested for Fischer-Tropsch Synthesis (FTS). Nano sized cobalt oxide structures upon pyrolysis and calcination have been verified. Upon DBP treatment, structural and compositional changes have been observed as well. Regarding FTS performance of these catalysts, plasma and non-plasma treated samples showed different patterns of conversion and products selectivity during FTS. Higher C2-C4 olefin and C5+ selectivity at the expense of paraffin selectivity was the most noticeable point for the plasma-assisted catalysts. FTS results for as-synthesized catalysts illustrated a novel method for plasma-assisted MOF-derived catalysts with modified surface physiochemical characteristics to simultaneously balance competing CO dissociation and chain growth reactions. Graphical abstract In the present paper, plasma treatment of a Co-based MOF (ZIF-67) followed by plasma treatment applied for Fischer–Tropsch synthesis (FTS) was considered. Various pattern of products selectivity was obtained for plasma and non-plasma treated samples. Higher C2-C4 olefins selectivity at the expense of paraffin’s selectivity was the most noticeable point for the plasma-assisted catalysts. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Zeolitic imidazolate framework Fischer–Tropsch synthesis Pyrolysis Plasma Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction There have been worldwide research efforts on environmentally friendly and sustainable technologies for manufacturing the commodity chemicals [1]. In this respect, Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) has become a subject of renewed interest in converting syngas, a mixture of CO, CO2 and H2, into synthetic fuels and chemicals [2]. Synthetic fuels via Fischer-Tropsch do not contain nitrogen, sulphur and aromatic organic compounds and would not cause any NOx, SO2 and PAH emissions when combusted. However, it is important to supply the syngas by sustainable ways and from carbon neutral sources such as biomass gasification or direct air captured CO2 plus green hydrogen to control the carbon emissions [3]. The Fischer-Tropsch reaction is a surface polymerization reaction that starts with CO activation into surface CHx species. Hydrocarbon chain growth and termination occur subsequently, resulting in the formation of either linear paraffins or 1-olefins. Cobalt (Co) and iron (Fe) have been extensively studied and established as highly effective catalysts for this reaction [4,5], with the choice of catalyst primarily dictated by the desired product selectivity Cobalt catalysts are known for their high selectivity toward methane (CH4) and long-chain hydrocarbons (C5 +), while exhibiting relatively low olefin selectivity. In contrast, iron catalysts offer higher olefin selectivity, making them suitable for applications where olefin-rich products are desired. The low water gas shift (WGS) activity makes the cobalt catalyst more suitable for hydrogen-rich syngas and thereby CO had not been wasted by its chemical shifting back to CO2. Cobalt catalyst is known to be more active and less prone to deactivation but is much more expensive than iron catalysts. For this reason, it is preferable to have it homogeneously dispersed over a high surface area support. Its reducibility at mild temperatures, dispersion level on the support material, and cobalt crystallite size collectively play a critical role in determining its overall catalytic activity. These factors influence the active site availability, interaction with the support, and the efficiency of the catalytic process, ultimately shaping the performance and selectivity of the catalyst [6]. The optimum cobalt crystalline size of 8–10 nm for the FTS reaction was generally agreed on [7]. However, the crystal growth of nanoparticles strongly depends on the cobalt-support interaction. CoO or Co3O4 crystallites can be stabilized by the formation of mixed cobalt-metal oxide layer at the interface [8]. However, this may cause the formation of hardly reducible mixed oxide phases ending up with deteriorated catalytic activity. Besides, when cobalt impregnation exceeds 20 % wt., considerable aggregation of cobalt particles becomes significant [9–12]. In response to these concerns, template-assisted methods can be employed such as the controlled pyrolysis/calcination of metal organic frameworks (MOFs) to prepare metal-oxide nanoparticles with relatively uniform size. The size and the morphology of transition metal oxide nanoparticles are affected not only by the thermal treatment conditions but also dependent on the concentration of metal centres, anisotropic structure and the strength of the coordination bonds of MOFs [13,14]. The formation of cobalt oxide nanoparticles through calcination has been thoroughly elucidated by Zhang et al. In their study, they demonstrated that during the initial stage of calcination, a dodecahedral Co3O4 shell forms on the surface of the ZIF-67 core. This process highlights the transformation dynamics of the material, offering valuable insights into the structural evolution and morphology of cobalt oxide nanoparticles [15]. During this stage, the amorphous carbon generated from the decomposition of the organic linker plays a pivotal role by acting as a temporary framework to facilitate the uniform distribution of Co or CoOx particles. As calcination progresses, two opposing forces at the interface between the Co3O4 shell and the ZIF-67 core drive the formation of a hollow structure loaded with nanoparticles. The contraction force arises from the crystallization of Co3O4, while the adhesive force is associated with the release of gases during the process. This interplay underpins the Kirkendall effect, which serves as the fundamental mechanism for fabricating caged Co3O4 structures using metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) as templates [16]. In case of pyrolysis of MOFs rather calcination, carbon-coated metal oxides can be obtained. By given the thermolysis process, the metal and metal oxide nanoparticles are formed as embedded in the carbon matrix [17]. Carbon encapsulation may limit the sintering of cobalt particles [18,19]. The resultant carbon doped with transition metals and nitrogen find well use as electrocatalysts for the oxygen reduction reaction in fuel cells [20]. In all these studies, both the initial MOF and thermal treatment routes may determine the morphology of the resultant metal/carbon nanocomposites. The temperature, time and atmosphere of thermal decomposition were revealed as key factors [21]. Because of its low cost and simple preparation, MOF derived cobalt catalysts widely proceed over ZIF-67 [22,23]. ZIF-67 combines the advantages of both zeolite and MOF structures together such as high surface area and porosity, chemical stability and thermal resistance. Moreover, N content from its organic linker might result in N-doped carbon and Co-N moieties that may contribute to the catalytic performance [24]. N-doping may enhance the electron donor capability of cobalt nanoparticles as in interacted with nitrogen doped sp2 hybridized carbon [25–28]. To avoid sintering and agglomeration of metal particles, cold plasma techniques have recently been preferred [29]. Regarding this, dielectric barrier plasma (DBP), one of the cold plasma techniques, may bring benefits in terms of improved metal dispersion, strength of active sites, hydrophilicity and electronic structure. Surface defects and oxygen vacancies may form on metal oxide nanosheets’ surface through lattice distortion and electronic compensation by argon plasma etching [30–32]. All these may enhance the overall catalytic activity. To the best of our knowledge, this study is among the first to systematically explore the application of dielectric barrier discharge (DBD) cold plasma treatment to MOF-derived cobalt catalysts specifically for Fischer–Tropsch synthesis. While cold plasma methods have been utilized for surface modification in other catalytic systems, their integration with MOF-templated cobalt oxide nanostructures remains relatively underexplored in FTS literature. The novelty of this approach lies in leveraging the non-thermal nature of cold plasma to introduce surface defects, enhance cobalt dispersion, and tailor the electronic and morphological properties of the catalyst without the excessive thermal stress associated with conventional treatments. This plasma-assisted strategy offers a new pathway to finely tune catalyst surfaces and improve product selectivity, particularly enhancing light olefin and C5 + yields at the expense of paraffins. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Nanostructured catalyst synthesis In a typical ZIF-67 synthesis, 800 mL of methanol (≥99.7 %, Mojalali Chemical Co, Iran) was used to separately dissolve 13.04 g of 2-methylimidazole (98 %, Aldrich) and 5.85 g of Cobalt (II) nitrate hexahydrate (Co (NO3)2·6H2O, 99 %, Merck, Germany) to have two uniform solutions. They were rapidly mixed and stirred overnight at room temperature. Then, the purple liquid was centrifuged (10,000 rpm, 5 min), washed five times with methanol, filtered and dried at 110 °C for 24 h as described elsewhere [33]. So formed ZIF-67 was pyrolyzed in a tube furnace under N2 flow for 4 h at temperatures (T) of 400, 500, 600, 700, 800 and 900 °C with a heating rate of 2 °C/min. A dielectric barrier discharge (DBD) was then applied for 30 min. Then, plasma treated samples were calcined at 350 °C for 3 h with a heating rate of 1 °C/min under air flow. The samples pyrolyzed at different temperatures were named as “CoZ@T” in which T represents the pyrolysis temperature while plasma treated ones as “P_CoZ@T” in which P represents the plasma treatment. 2.2 Characterization techniques X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) measurements were acquired using a Bruker, D8-Advance (Germany) by using Cu Kα (λ = 1.5418 A °) radiation. Surface morphologies were imaged by field emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM, Hitachi S- 4800). The elemental composition was determined using energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDAX). Surface functional groups were investigated by Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy on a Bruker, VECTOR 22 spectrometer with a 4 cm-1 resolution in transmission mode at room temperature. Total surface area was obtained by the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method through N2 isotherm at 77.35 K using Quantachrome® ASiQwin™ Anton Paar Autosorb IQ-MP. Before surface area measurements, the samples were degassed at 230 °C under vacuum for 10 h. Pore size distribution was estimated by Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) method. Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out using TA Instrument TGA 55. Temperature programmed reduction (TPR) profiles were obtained by flowing the gas mixture of 20 % H2 and 80 % N2 over ∼10 mg sample at a heating rate of 5 °C/min from ambient to 800 °C on thermal gravimetric analyser (TGA). Residual carbon on spent catalysts was measured by Vario MACRO cube elemental analyser using ASTM D 4239–12 method. The Raman spectroscopy (Rigaku, 1064 nm, US) were used to evaluate the characteristics D and G bands of graphitic carbon. 2.3 Performance tests for Fischer-Tropsch synthesis Fischer-Tropsch Synthesis (FTS) reaction tests were carried out on a high-pressure fixed bed reactor set-up (i.d.: 10 mm; length: 800 mm). To prevent condensation, all product streamlines were heat traced. 0.5 g of each catalyst (50–150 µm) was diluted with quartz particles with the same volume to prevent hot spots and were charged to the reactor. Before FTS reaction, catalysts were reduced with a gas mixture (50 %H2–50 %N2 vol based) at 400 °C for 16 h at atmospheric pressure. FTS reactor conditions were set as 230 °C and 15 bars, and 14.5 mL.min-1 flow of 64v % H2 / 29v % CO / 7v % N2 (corresponding to a space velocity of 1.8 L/gcat.h). Gas product composition was analysed by online gas chromatography (7820A GC, Agilent). Thermal conductivity detector (TCD) with a Carboxen column was used to quantitatively determine the amounts of H2, CO, CO2, and N2. Flame ionization detector (FID) with Alumina S column was for C1-C5+ hydrocarbons detection. Gas chromatography instrument was calibrated with known composition gas mixtures. (4). xn (HC) is the mole fraction of the hydrocarbon in the product stream as determined from GC analysis. 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Characterizations of ZIF-67 XRD, FTIR and N2 adsorption isotherm measurements for fresh ZIF-67 have been shown in Fig. 1 as in a), b) and c) and morphological characterization results of ZIF-67 were given in Fig. 2 as of a) FESEM and b) EDAX c) dot mapping. The crystalline structure of ZIF-67 was verified by XRD (JCPDS No. 41–1487) [34]. In FTIR analysis, the peaks at 697 and 760 cm-1 were given to due to the imidazole ring bending in out of plane range. Peaks in range of 600–1500 cm-1 have been related to the bending vibration in structural plane. The peaks at 1350−1500 cm-1 and the peak at 1589 cm-1 were attributed to the ring stretching and C = N bonds stretching, respectively [35]. While the peaks at 2930 cm-1 and at 3140 cm-1 can be ascribed to the C − H bonds of aliphatic chain and the aromatic ring of the imidazole, the bands at 1580 and 1663 cm-1 might be from N − H stretching and bending vibrations, respectively. Finally, the peaks at 3200−3700 cm-1 have shown the presence of bonded water in the structure. In summary, FTIR have well proved the successful synthesis of ZIF-67 structure. The N2 adsorption isotherm has shown Type-I plot indicating its microporous nature. The BET surface area of the ZIF-67 was calculated as 1824 m2/g with a total pore volume of 0.6 cm3/g and an average pore size of 1.37 nm. As shown in its SEM image, ZIF-67 crystals were in polyhedrons with smooth surfaces with an average size of 500 nm. EDAX results represented uniform distribution of C, N, Co and O in ZIF-67. The unexpected presence of oxygen could be a result of the superficial oxidation of cobalt in air [36]. 3.2 Characterizations of ZIF-67 derived FTS catalysts 3.2.1 XRD Fig. 3 illustrates the XRD patterns of the catalysts. Diffraction peaks corresponding to the (111), (220), (311), (400), (422), (511), (440), and (533) planes of the Co3O4 phase (JCPDS: 42–1467) were detected at 2θ values of 19°, 31.3°, 37.1°, 44.8°, 55.65°, 59.4°, 65.2°, and 77.34°, respectively [29]. Notably, no diffraction peaks related to CoO or other impurity phases were observed, confirming the complete conversion of the ZIF-67 precursor into the pure Co3O4 phase. Table 1 presents the crystallite size of Co3O4 calculated using the Scherrer equation based on the full width at half-maximum (FWHM) of the XRD peaks. The crystallite sizes ranged between 31 and 58 nm, confirming the nanostructured nature of the samples. An upward trend in the intensity of the major Co3O4 peaks was observed with increasing pyrolysis temperature, up to 600 °C, indicating improved crystallinity. Beyond this temperature, no further increase in crystallinity was noted. Interestingly, the cold plasma treatment did not significantly influence the crystallite size of Co3O4 across all pyrolysis temperatures. However, a slight shift of XRD peaks to smaller angles was observed in plasma-treated samples, potentially indicating an expanded lattice spacing. This shift may be attributed to the presence of oxygen vacancies (OVs), which result in the formation of Co³⁺ ions with a larger ionic radius compared to Co²⁺, as well as a wider van der Waals gap. To evaluate the effect of plasma treatment on the crystalline structure, a comparison was made between plasma-treated and non-plasma-treated samples at the same pyrolysis temperature, e.g., CoZ@400 and P_CoZ@400. The XRD patterns of plasma-treated samples remained consistent with those of their non-plasma-treated counterparts. However, a reduction in peak intensity and broadening were observed for plasma-treated samples, suggesting a potential loss of long-range order and/or the formation of missing-linker defects. These changes might also result from improved dispersion of cobalt oxide within the carbon matrix. The reduction in peak intensity was particularly pronounced in plasma-treated samples pyrolyzed at 600 °C. For a clearer illustration of the peak shift, the diffraction peak corresponding to the (311) plane is shown in Fig. 3. According to Bragg’s law (nλ=2dsinθ), a shift to smaller angles indicates an expanded lattice spacing (d). This effect is consistent with the presence of oxygen vacancies, increased Co3+ formation with larger ion radius compared to Co2+, and a wider van der Waals gap. In summary, the XRD analysis reveals that the plasma treatment induces structural modifications in the Co3O4 phase, primarily affecting lattice spacing, peak intensity, and long-range order, while the overall crystallite size remains unaffected. 3.2.2 FTIR Fig. 4 gives the FT-IR spectra in the range of 500–4000 cm−1. FT-IR analysis results were consistent with the obtained XRD patterns showing the presence of Co3O4 phase. Two characteristic bands of the spinel-type Co3O4 structure have been clearly marked at 676 cm−1 for Co3+–O vibration in an octahedral site and 570 cm−1 for Co2+–O vibration in a tetrahedral site of the Co3O4 lattice [37]. While pyrolysis temperature did not have any remarkable effect on FT-IR peaks, plasma treatment led to an increase in peak intensities related to octahedral coordinated Co3+–O and a decrease in peak intensities of the tetrahedrally coordinated Co2+–O. This structural change upon plasma treatment was clearer up to the pyrolysis temperatures of 700 °C and might influence the activity of the catalyst [38]. This result agreed with XRD peak shifts to lower angles upon plasma treatment. Additionally, the observed weak peaks at 2920 and 2880 cm-1 can be assigned to the C − H bonds of aliphatic chain confirming the carbon residue upon pyrolysis. The intensity of these peaks diminished slightly in plasma-treated samples, indicating partial removal of carbonaceous material, which aligns with the reduced carbon content observed in dot mapping. Lastly, the vague peak around 1630 cm-1 might be the indicative of stretching and bending vibrations of nitrogen atoms in relation with carbon and hydrogen, possibly in relation to C–N and N–H bonds. Nitrogen atoms might generate permanent dipoles via C-N bonding due to its higher electronegativity than carbon and introduces p-electrons in the graphitic carbon plane. Consequently, it may result in enhanced surface energy that might give high catalytic activity [39]. 3.2.3 FESEM Fig. 5 displays the FESEM images of the catalysts prepared at various pyrolysis temperatures, with and without plasma treatment. Initially, the hexagonal-shaped ZIF-67 particles transformed into berry-like spherical clusters after pyrolysis. These spherical clusters exhibited a tendency to agglomerate as the pyrolysis temperature increased. For example, the clusters in CoZ@400 were observed to range in size from 59 to 75 nm, while those in CoZ@600 exhibited a broader size range of 39 to 149 nm, highlighting the temperature-dependent morphological variations. Upon closer examination, the agglomerated clusters were found to consist of fine particles embedded within the larger clusters. This suggests that higher pyrolysis temperatures not only promoted particle growth but also enhanced particle aggregation, potentially due to the sintering of cobalt oxide nanoparticles. Additionally, an increase in pyrolysis temperature led to a more pronounced particle fusion, diminishing the distinct boundaries between individual clusters. The plasma-treated samples showed significant changes in surface morphology. Notably, the surface roughness of plasma-treated catalysts became more pronounced compared to the smoother surfaces of non-plasma-treated cobalt oxide samples. This increased roughness is likely attributed to the sputtering and etching effects caused by energetic particle bombardment during plasma treatment. The plasma bombardment might also introduce surface defects, such as oxygen vacancies, which could improve catalytic activity. Moreover, plasma treatment appeared to disrupt the uniformity of the spherical clusters, resulting in partially fractured structures and a more irregular morphology. This disruption may indicate enhanced dispersion of cobalt oxide particles in the carbon matrix, which can be beneficial for catalytic applications. For instance, P_CoZ@600 showed visibly rougher surfaces and more dispersed features than its non-plasma-treated counterpart, CoZ@600. At higher pyrolysis temperatures, such as 800 °C and 900 °C, the plasma-treated samples exhibited further structural changes, including reduced long-range order and increased porosity, which could be linked to enhanced gas diffusion and active site exposure during catalytic reactions. Additionally, the plasma treatment seems to have influenced the size distribution of the clusters. In plasma-treated samples, a more uniform distribution of fine particles within the clusters was observed, potentially reflecting improved cobalt dispersion and reduced particle agglomeration. This structural refinement could enhance the availability of active sites for catalytic reactions. Overall, the FESEM analysis demonstrates that both pyrolysis temperature and plasma treatment play critical roles in determining the morphological characteristics of the catalysts. Higher pyrolysis temperatures promote cluster growth and agglomeration, while plasma treatment enhances surface roughness, introduces defects, and improves cobalt oxide dispersion, which are all favourable traits for catalytic performance. Increased surface roughness may help the reactants (CO and H₂) adsorption onto the active sites and facilitate the activation of CO that is a critical step in Fischer-Tropsch synthesis and in responsible for the observed high initial activity. However, structural degradation deteriorating the catalytic stability and/or changing selectivity towards undesired products sould also be considered with excessive defects or roughness [40]. So, plasma treatment parameters (e.g., power, duration, gas composition) should be well-balanced to control the extent of surface roughness and defect formation [41]. In conclusion, FESEM analysis underscores the critical influence of pyrolysis temperature and plasma treatment on catalyst morphology. While higher pyrolysis temperatures promote cluster growth and agglomeration, plasma treatment enhances surface roughness, introduces beneficial defects, disrupts cluster uniformity, and improves cobalt oxide dispersion. These combined effects contribute positively to catalytic performance by increasing active site exposure, enhancing gas diffusion, and improving overall reactivity. 3.2.4 EDAX-dot mapping Fig. 6 and Table 2 displays the EDAX, and dot mapping images of the catalysts synthesized respectively. These images highlight the spatial distribution of key elements (C, N, Co, O) within the samples. The comparison between plasma-treated and non-plasma-treated catalysts reveals significant differences in elemental distribution and surface characteristics. For all samples, cobalt (Co) appears to be uniformly distributed over the residual carbon matrix. Plasma-treated samples exhibited improved cobalt dispersion compared to their non-plasma-treated counterparts. This enhancement may result from the sputtering and etching effects of plasma, which facilitate the redistribution of cobalt species and increase the exposure of active sites on the catalyst surface. Particularly in P_CoZ@600 and P_CoZ@800, cobalt enrichment is more apparent, indicating the plasma's ability to improve surface accessibility and reduce agglomeration of cobalt oxides. A noticeable decrease in carbon density was observed upon plasma treatment, as evidenced by the reduced intensity of the carbon (C) signal in the dot maps of plasma-treated samples. This reduction may be attributed to plasma-induced removal of carbonaceous residues, leaving behind a cleaner surface with better exposure of cobalt oxide particles [42]. The reduction in carbon density is most pronounced at higher pyrolysis temperatures, such as P_CoZ@800 and P_CoZ@900, which aligns with the increasing thermal stability of the carbon matrix at elevated temperatures. Gradual nitrogen enrichment was observed in the plasma-treated samples, as shown by the stronger nitrogen (N) signals in the dot maps. This increase in nitrogen content correlates with the formation of nitrogen-doped carbon structures, as confirmed by FTIR analysis. Nitrogen doping is likely facilitated by the plasma treatment, which incorporates nitrogen from the precursor's organic linkers into the carbon matrix. This structural modification enhances the electron-donor capability of the catalysts and contributes to improved catalytic performance. 3.2.5 BET-BJH The 12 synthesized samples were categorized into two sections based on their pyrolysis temperatures: low-temperature pyrolyzed samples (400–600 °C) and high-temperature pyrolyzed samples (700–900 °C). This division allows for a more systematic comparison of the textural properties, such as surface area, pore size, and pore volume between the two groups. The results for each category will be presented and analyzed in separate figures to highlight the impact of pyrolysis temperature on the catalyst's structural characteristics. To study the influence of the pyrolysis temperature and plasma treatment on the pore structure of Co/C catalysts, N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms were used. The results were given in Figs. 7–9 . As shown in Fig. 7, the N₂ adsorption–desorption isotherms of the low-temperature pyrolyzed samples (400–600 °C) correspond to Type II isotherms according to the IUPAC classification. Type II isotherms, which lack a distinct saturation plateau, are indicative of multilayer adsorption on non-porous or macroporous materials with a wide pore size distribution. At p/p₀ < 0.05, the adsorption isotherms exhibited a sudden and sharp increase with rising p/p₀, suggesting the presence of residual micropores despite the pyrolysis treatment. A significant reduction in BET surface area and porosity was observed in comparison to the pristine ZIF-67 precursor. BET surface area and pore volume of fresh ZIF-67 were measured as 1824 m²/g and 0.6 cm³/g, respectively. However, upon pyrolysis, these values dropped substantially, with BET surface areas ranging from 10 to 40 m²/g and pore volumes decreasing to 0.01 to 0.05 cm³/g. This dramatic decline can be attributed to the collapse of the ZIF-67 framework and the formation of cobalt oxide particles, which occupy and block the pores during thermal decomposition. All catalyst samples experienced a significant loss of textural properties due to pyrolysis and calcination, leading to a reduction in specific surface area and pore volume, along with an increase in pore width, indicating a transition to mesoporous structures. This transformation highlights the collapse of the ZIF-67 framework at elevated temperatures, with the lowest surface area observed at 600 °C. Plasma treatment further reduced surface area and pore volume, while minimally affecting pore size. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms for the samples pyrolyzed at 700–900 °C, with and without plasma treatment, are shown in the Fig. 8. All isotherms exhibit Type II behaviour. Plasma-treated samples display lower adsorption volumes compared to their non-plasma-treated counterparts, as evidenced by the slightly flatter isotherms. From 700 °C to 800 °C as shown in Fig. 9, an increase in pore volume is noted, indicating the formation of mesopores. This could be attributed to the partial removal of residual carbon, leading to the exposure of larger voids. From 800 °C to 900 °C, a decrease in pore volume occurs, likely due to increased sintering and particle aggregation at the higher temperature, which blocks pores and further collapses the porous structure. 3.2.6 H2-TGA The TGA profiles of fresh catalysts were given in Figs. 10 and 11 . In general, the TPR peak temperatures exhibited a clear upward trend with increasing pyrolysis temperature, regardless of plasma treatment. High temperature TPR peak of cobalt oxide may have shown a split into two separate peaks [43]. The first peak of this splitting can be ascribed to the reduction of Co2+ → Co° from the surface of Co3O4 nanoparticles while the second peak of this splitting can be due to the reduction of bulk Co3O4 nanoparticles. In our study, two TPR peaks at 298 °C and 397 °C were observed for the catalyst, CoZ@400 whereas the others showed only one distinct TPR peak at around 350–400 °C. In some of the TPR profiles, the low temperature peak of 298 °C can be vaguely distinguished as a shoulder, e.g., CoZ@500 and P_CoZ@400. Moreover, a small peak weight loss of 5.3–6.8 % has been noticed above 550 °C as well. In consistent with the literature, it may be claimed that the reduction has occurred on the surface of Co3O4 nanoparticles. On the other hand, a shift in the TPR peaks to higher temperatures was noted upon plasma treatment. For example, the TPR temperatures of CoZ@700, CoZ@800 and CoZ@900 catalysts were 409 °C, 410 °C and 382 °C, respectively and these TPR peaks were shifted to 423 °C, 414 °C and 426 °C upon plasma treatment. Higher temperatures of TPR peak might be due to the “strong metal surface interaction” (SMSI) effect. Since the reduction temperature depends on the crystal size, reduction level and support-metal oxide interaction, deviations of TPR peak temperatures may also be attributed to the changing crystal sizes depending on the pre-treatment conditions [44]. 3.2.7 Raman spectroscopy The Raman spectra of the catalysts up to 1000 cm-1 at 782 nm have been given in Fig. 12 . The presence of nanocrystaline Co3O4 have been confirmed by the Raman peaks at 196, 482, 522, 619 and 691cm−1 [45]. The peaks at 466 and 672 cm−1 could be attributed to Eg and A1g vibration modes and the peaks at 196 and 522 cm−1 were ascribed to F2g Raman vibration mode, respectively. The peak at 672 cm−1 was assigned to the vibration of the octahedral sites and the peak at 196 cm−1 corresponded to the vibration of the tetrahedral sites. From the intensity ratio of IA1g against IF2g, one can estimate the relative amount of Co3+ and Co2+[46]. IA1g/IF2g ratios were given in Table 3 . It was shown that plasma treatment has led to an increase in Co2+ concentration except the catalyst, CoZ@700 which exhibited high Co2+ concentration both for its plasma and non-plasma treated forms. Moreover, the increase in full width half maximum (FWHM) values by plasma treatment has suggested the formation of crystal defects. It appears that plasma treatment has favoured the formation of cobalt spinel phase containing both cobalt ions in Co2+ and Co3+ oxidation states with defect sites. These characterization results pointed out that plasma treatment may induce the surface chemistry by providing the new functional groups (C–N, C = N, –NH, –NH3+ and =NH) to the residual carbon surface [47]. These can help to create the new active sites besides contributing to stronger interaction between the cobalt oxides and the functional groups on carbon. This has been evidenced by the shift in TPR peak to high temperatures, a remarkable increase in the intensity ratio of IA1g against IF2g in the Raman Spectrum and dispersion characteristics by EDAX-dot mapping. Plasma treatment has obviously favored the formation of cobalt spinel phase containing both cobalt ions of Co2+ and Co3+. Since cobalt particles were likely to be anchored on carbon functional groups, improved cobalt dispersion might be reasonable due to the high resistance of anchored cobalt particles to aggregation. The presence of CoO phase as verified by Raman Spectroscopy may be formed via the partial reduction of Co3O4 as given below [48]: 2Co3O4 + C → 6CoO + CO2 The coexistence of Co2+ and Co3+ ions with its unique electronic structure might facilitate the defect formation. Their interaction under cold plasma conditions may further destabilize the Co3O4 spinel structure by potentially displacing the oxygen atoms in the lattice to create vacancies as well. Disruption of cobalt oxide clusters into smaller could improve accessibility to active sites [49]. Ultimately, these structural alterations could enhance the dispersion of cobalt oxide particles. 3.3 Catalytic performance study toward FTS 3.2.1 H2 & CO conversion FOR FTS Fig. 13 shows average conversions in every 10 h time on stream Fisher-Tropsch Synthesis (a) CO conversion for Low temperature pyrolyzed samples (b) CO conversion for High temperature pyrolyzed samples (c) H2 conversion for Low temperature pyrolyzed samples and (d) H2 conversion for High temperature pyrolyzed samples. CoZ@600 was seen to have the highest initial CO conversion of 39.8 % among the non-plasma treated samples. However, a drop of CO conversion to 24.7 % was observed with an overall average CO conversion of 31.3 %. On the other hand, CoZ@400 and CoZ@500 had initially a lower but more stable CO conversions compared to CoZ@600. The overall average CO conversion over CoZ@400 and CoZ@500 were calculated to be ∼29.0 % and ∼19.2 %. For the pyrolysis temperatures above 600 °C, CO conversions at around 13–17 % were much lower compared to the ones at pyrolysis temperatures at or below 600 °C. Regarding H2 conversions, less H2 conversions were obtained in general as compared to CO conversions. For example, the average values of CO and H2 conversions over CoZ@600 were 31.3 % and 29.8 %, respectively. This can be reasonable due to the poor water gas shift activity of cobalt-based catalyst. In the other side, a marked difference between CO and H2 conversions was noticed in some cases, i.e. pyrolysis temperature of 400 °C where average CO and H2 conversions were 29 % and 22.5 %, respectively. The higher CO conversions can be regarded as the occurrence of Boudouard reaction due to the favouring low-temperature FTS condition. When all results were compared, overall average CO conversions over non-plasma treated catalysts were shown to be in the order of CoZ@600 > CoZ@400 > CoZ@500 > CoZ@700 > CoZ@800 > CoZ@900. All these were evidenced the structural change on cobalt oxide catalysts depending on the pyrolysis temperatures. Looking at the plasma treated catalyst results, CO and H2 conversion were seen to be steadily high on P-CoZ@600. The average CO and H2 conversions were 24.0 % and 15.9 %, respectively. P_CoZ@900 has also shown high average CO and H2 conversions of 25.6 % and 23.6 %. However, the high conversion with P_CoZ@900 was because of its high initial activity, and that this catalyst was rapidly deactivating. In parallel to the results over non-plasma treated catalysts, plasma-treated samples pyrolyzed at 600 °C and above have also shown a poor catalytic performance except for P_CoZ@900. When the activity of P_CoZ@900 was omitted, the same order of activity was seen upon plasma treatments as in the order of P_CoZ@600 > P_CoZ@400 ∼P_CoZ@500 > P_CoZ@700 > P_CoZ@800. An interesting point was that although high CO conversions were recorded on plasma treated samples initially, loss of activity was more severe showing catalytic instability as brought by plasma treatment. Altered oxidation states of cobalt by plasma treatment was obvious and likely have influence on catalytic behaviour. The initial high CO conversion observed for plasma treated catalysts can be regarded as enhanced reactivity of plasma-induced defects and oxygen vacancies. However, excessive defect formation may lead to structural instability causing rapid deactivation. This pointed out the need for optimization of plasma treatment conditions to maintain the stability of plasma-modified cobalt catalysts [49–51]. The superior catalytic performance observed in the Fischer–Tropsch synthesis over CoZ@600 and plasma-treated high-temperature catalysts (P_CoZ@800, P_CoZ@900) can be directly linked to their distinct structural and physicochemical characteristics. XRD analysis revealed that CoZ@600 exhibited the highest crystallinity among low temperature pyrolyzed samples, correlating with its maximum CO and H₂ conversion. In contrast, plasma-treated samples at higher pyrolysis temperatures maintained sufficient crystallinity while introducing beneficial structural defects, such as oxygen vacancies, as evidenced by XRD peak shifts and intensified Co³⁺–O bands in FTIR spectra. These vacancies enhance the presence of surface Co³⁺ sites, which are more reducible and catalytically active for CO dissociation. Additionally, Raman spectroscopy confirmed the generation of Co²⁺ species and crystal defects following plasma treatment, promoting H₂ activation. Morphological analysis using FESEM and EDAX demonstrated improved cobalt dispersion, reduced agglomeration, and increased surface roughness in plasma-treated catalysts, enhancing active site accessibility. Although plasma treatment resulted in a decrease in surface area (BET), it simultaneously facilitated the formation of mesopores—especially at 800 °C—supporting better gas diffusion and exposure of active sites. Furthermore, H₂-TGA profiles showed shifts in reduction temperatures for plasma-treated samples, suggesting stronger metal–support interaction (SMSI) and enhanced thermal stability of active Co₃O₄ phases. The presence of both surface and bulk Co species in CoZ@400, inferred from TPR peak splitting, may explain its relatively high activity in the absence of plasma. Overall, the interplay of improved crystallinity, defect engineering, and tailored morphology through controlled pyrolysis and plasma treatment is pivotal in optimizing the catalytic behaviour of the Co-based catalysts for FT synthesis. 3.2.2 Products selectivity The overall average hydrocarbon selectivity values after 40 hr were given in Table 4 . Detailed product distribution was shown on Figs. 14 and 15 . The first point that should be remarked here that all catalysts with or without plasma treatment have shown high methane selectivity among all hydrocarbon products. For the highly active four catalysts in terms of CO conversions, CoZ@400, CoZ@600, P_CoZ@600 and P_CoZ@900, methane selectivity was around 31.6–35.2 %. It was clearly seen that non-plasma treated ones of these four catalysts had higher C2-C4 paraffin selectivity as of 25.2 % and 24.2 % on CoZ@400 and CoZ@600, respectively. In the other side, light olefin and C5+ selectivity was higher over plasma treated catalyst, P_CoZ@600. Light olefin and C5+ selectivity of 21.3 % and 27.8 % were recorded for P_CoZ@600 whereas those values were 13.8 % and 26.3 % for CoZ@600, respectively. As a plausible explanation, plasma treatment might have more active sites accelerating olefins re-adsorption thereby, the surface polymerization reactions proceed to give a rise in C5+ selectivity. At the same time, the growing alkyl chain on the surface ending up with β-elimination of hydrides might give rise to olefin selectivity as well. All these have supported the fact that the nature of catalytic surfaces could be altered upon plasma treatment and thereby may lead to facilitated the surface oligomeric species formation terminating by light olefins and C5 +hydrocarbons. To investigate any correlation between the hydrogenation activity of FTS catalysts with the H/C ratio of the spent catalysts as a measure of surface -(CHx) n- concentration, elemental analysis was applied on the spent catalysts. The analysis results on H/C ratio of spent catalysts were given in Table 4. As seen in the Table 4, the most active catalysts, namely CoZ@400, CoZ@600 and P_CoZ@900, have shown higher H/C ratio of around 0.15. A H/C ratio of 0.15 might be indicative of the surface CH∼1.8 formation. In the other side, a lower H/C ratio can be ascribed to the carbon deposition due to the unbalanced CO dissociation and hydrocarbon chain growth as in the case of CoZ@700 and P_CoZ@800. So, both the pyrolysis temperature and the plasma treatment seemed to be critical parameters as a measure of catalytic activity. The FTS product distributions (Figs. 14 and 15) demonstrate a clear correlation between catalyst structure—modulated by pyrolysis temperature and plasma treatment—and hydrocarbon selectivity. At lower pyrolysis temperatures (400–600 °C), plasma-treated catalysts (e.g., P_CoZ@400 and P_CoZ@500) exhibited enhanced selectivity toward longer-chain hydrocarbons (C5 +) and C₂–C₄ olefins, while simultaneously suppressing methane formation compared to their non-plasma counterparts. This could be ascribed to the effect of structural modification on the catalytic pathway in Fischer-Tropsch Synthesis. Align with the XRD and Raman findings, plasma treatment has introduced lattice distortions and oxygen vacancies and increased the Co²⁺ content—both of which are known to enhance CO activation and chain propagation. Creation of oxygen vacancies and surface defects by plasma treatment led to increase in the number of active sites available for olefin re-adsorption. This might have allowed these intermediates to undergo further chain growth reactions favoring C₅+ hydrocarbons. Altered electronic environment of the active sites seemed to favor the termination reaction by β-elimination over hydrogenation. The cleavage of hydrogen atom from the β-carbon over the modified active sites might have yielded the formation of unsaturated hydrocarbons as of C2-C4 olefins. Plasma treatment might shift the product selectivity by modifying the catalytic surface, leading to the observed changes in selectivity [41,52]. At higher pyrolysis temperatures (700–900 °C), plasma-treated catalysts maintained relatively high olefin selectivity and minimized CH4 production, particularly in P_CoZ@800 and P_CoZ@900. This performance can be attributed to improved cobalt dispersion (confirmed by EDAX-dot mapping), nitrogen doping (evident in FTIR and Raman data), and a more defective carbon matrix, as observed in FESEM images. Furthermore, the H₂-TPR results indicated stronger metal-support interactions (SMSI) and shifted reduction temperatures in plasma-treated samples, which may stabilize cobalt oxide phases and enhance their catalytic lifetime. BET-BJH analysis revealed that plasma treatment decreased surface area but contributed to higher dispersion and mesoporosity at optimal temperatures (∼800 °C), possibly facilitating better diffusion and access to active sites. Collectively, these structural and textural modifications provided by plasma-assisted synthesis and optimal thermal treatment directly influence chain growth probability and olefin/paraffin ratios in the FTS reaction. 4 Conclusions Nano sized cobalt oxide structures upon pyrolysis and calcination have been verified. In the pyrolysis step, N content of the organic linker in ZIF-67 synthesis helped to prepare N doped carbon and Co-N moieties. Proving the efficacy of DBP treatment, structural and compositional changes such as expanded space distance, surface roughness, increased surface nitrogen content and the dominance of octahedral coordinated Co3+-O structure over tetrahedral coordinated Co2+-O structure were observed. Higher temperatures of TPR peak maxima for plasma-treated samples were interpreted as having “strong metal surface interaction” (SMSI). Regarding FTS performance of these catalysts, even when the reaction started with high CO conversions on the plasma treated catalysts, CO conversions on average were lower compared to the catalyst without plasma treatment. This was possibly due to the altered surface nature and decreased number of active sites through coking. The fact that light olefin and C5+ selectivity were higher upon plasma treatment, it may be proposed that plasma treatment have led to the creation of active surfaces accelerating olefins re-adsorption thereby, the surface polymerization reactions proceed further to give C5+ selectivity. The surface alkyl chains ending up with β-elimination of hydrides might be the other reason for the observed high olefin selectivity upon plasma. This has been supported by Raman Spectroscopy results where disorders and defects in graphite structure on plasma treated catalysts have been noticed. coredata.dc:description: ZIF-67 type metal organic framework (MOF) has been synthesized and pyrolyzed at six different temperatures to prepare cobalt nanoparticles encapsulated by carbon. In the pyrolysis step, N content of the organic linker in ZIF-67 synthesis helped to prepare N doped carbon and Co-N moieties. Dielectric barrier plasma (DBP) has been used in succession with pyrolysis to benefit from its less destructive effects during decomposition to generate more active sites through lattice distortion. All catalysts have been characterized and tested for Fischer-Tropsch Synthesis (FTS). Nano sized cobalt oxide structures upon pyrolysis and calcination have been verified. Upon DBP treatment, structural and compositional changes have been observed as well. Regarding FTS performance of these catalysts, plasma and non-plasma treated samples showed different patterns of conversion and products selectivity during FTS. Higher C2-C4 olefin and C5+ selectivity at the expense of paraffin selectivity was the most noticeable point for the plasma-assisted catalysts. FTS results for as-synthesized catalysts illustrated a novel method for plasma-assisted MOF-derived catalysts with modified surface physiochemical characteristics to simultaneously balance competing CO dissociation and chain growth reactions.
